Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 50266-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance Facility (F-TRTA) 
December 2018 
 
 
 
Southeast Asia Agriculture, Natural Resources and 
Rural Development Facility 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ANR  –  agriculture, natural resources and rural development 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  DED  –  detailed engineering design 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  PRITF  –  Project Readiness Improvement Trust Fund 
  QCBS  –  quality- and cost-based selection 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
Vice-President  Stephen Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  Ramesh Subramaniam, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  Jiangfeng Zhang, Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture 
Division, SERD

SERD

of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will provide project preparation support, 
project implementation support, capacity building, and policy advice to a series of ongoing and 
ensuing projects in the agriculture, natural resources, and rural development (ANR) sector in the 
developing member countries (DMCs) in Southeast Asia in line with Strategy 2030 during 2018–
2023.1 The ANR sector plays a key role in ensuring inclusive economic growth in the region and 
has high priority in the respective national development strategies.2 The TA facility approach will 
enhance efficiency in project preparation and administration by (i) reducing time and effort for TA 
processing, approval, and administration; and (ii) accelerating the consultant recruitment process 
by prequalifying consultants for all the project preparation and implementation support under the 
facility. 
 
1.  Background 
 
2.  Remarkable economic growth and poverty reduction. The Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN) region, comprising 10 Southeast Asian countries, is home to over 622 
million people. It has the third largest labor force in the world, behind only the People’s Republic 
of China and India. With an average annual economic growth of 5.3% during 2007–2015, ASEAN 
has consistently outperformed global economic growth. ASEAN’s combined gross domestic 
products in 2015 stood at $2.4 trillion (sixth largest economy in the world).3 The robust economic 
performance enabled the region to reduce the proportion of populations below the respective 
national poverty lines from 31% in 1990 to 14% in 2015.4 
 
3.  Increasing rural-urban income disparity. Despite the remarkable poverty reduction, 
there are still 36 million people in the region living below the international poverty line.5 The 
economic growth driven by industrial and service sectors centered in urban areas has left the 
large population in rural areas outside the stream of viable economic opportunities. The widening 
rural-urban income disparity within countries has been recognized as a common symptom.6 To 
make economic growth equitable, inclusive, and sustainable, investing in urban development is 
not  sufficient.  Vitalizing  rural  economies  is  imperative  as  the  region  is  endowed  with  rich 
agricultural and natural resources, and with large populations engaged in agriculture. 
 
                                                
1  The TA facility will initially provide project preparation support for three ensuing projects for Myanmar and Viet Nam, 
and project implementation support to ongoing projects such as the L3724-MYA and Grant 0617-MYA Climate-
Friendly Agribusiness Value Chains Sector project. These projects are listed in Appendix 2. The ensuing projects 
and relevant TAs are in the Country Operations Business Plans of the respective DMCs. With additional funds 
including Technical Assistance Special Fund for 2019, more projects for additional DMCs in Southeast Asia will be 
added under the TA facility. 
2  These strategies include Myanmar’s Five-Year Development Plan 2016/2017-2020/2021 and Viet Nam’s Five-Year 
Socio-Economic Development Plan (2016–2020). 
3  ASEAN. 2016. ASEAN in 2016. Jakarta. 
4  ASEAN. 2017. ASEAN Statistical Report on Millennium Development Goals 2017. Jakarta. 
5  ASEAN Secretariat News. 2017. Launched: Publication on financing the Sustainable Development Goals in ASEAN. 
17 November.  
6  Not a single ASEAN nation could be considered one of the more equitable economies globally. A. Mordecai. 2017. 
What is the Future of Integration and Inequality in ASEAN? The Diplomat. 15 September.

2 
2.  Sector Challenges 
4.  Low rural labor productivity. The increasing rural-urban income disparity is largely 
attributable to low rural labor productivity. The DMCs have substantial rural populations, whose 
shares in total populations vary from the lowest in Indonesia (46.3%) to the highest in Cambodia 
(79.3%). Rural labor opportunities in the region are largely in rice-dominant, small-scale, and low 
mechanized farming.7 A large portion of the rural workforce is engaged in subsistent agriculture 
and underemployed. It is crucial for the DMCs to generate productive economic opportunities for 
rural populations by diversifying the sector and building backward and forward linkages within the 
sector. 
 
5.  Increasing demand for a wide variety of safe food. Due to increased income and 
awareness for a safe and balanced diet, the people in the region demand a variety of high quality 
and more nutritious food products. Because food products are produced and transported by 
multiple players in the food value chains, it is more difficult to trace causes of food adulteration 
and contamination. The extended food value chains and wide variety of food products have made 
law enforcement on food safety control a challenge. While food safety laws have become more 
stringent in the DMCs, their capacity to enforce food safety laws is still limited. 
 
6.  Underdeveloped agro-based value chains. To achieve inclusive growth in the region, 
the ANR sector needs to become more competitive and generate productive off- and non-farm 
jobs. Agro-based value chain development is the key to realize this. However, value chains of 
most agriculture products in the DMCs are underdeveloped because of insufficient private sector 
investment caused by various constraints: (i) underdeveloped infrastructure; (ii) limited access to 
long-term affordable finance for a great majority of business entities in the sector (i.e., micro-, 
small- and medium-sized enterprises and cooperatives); and (iii) sourcing raw materials from 
many scattered small farmers. 
 
7.  Natural resources degradation and environmental pollution. The region is endowed 
with rich natural resources, which are pivotal in sustaining a wide range of economic activities 
and livelihoods. However, natural resources intensive agricultural growth has caused immense 
natural  resources  degradation  and  environmental  pollution.  Environmentally  unsustainable 
farming practices, resource-intensive industrial agricultural production, poor management of 
commercial plantations, and an increasing volume of agricultural products that require transport 
have all contributed to the degradation of natural resources and environmental pollution. It is 
important to take a holistic approach to make the performance of agro-based value chains 
resource-efficient and green. 
 
8.  Climate change impacts. The region is highly vulnerable to climate change as a large 
proportion of population and economic activity is concentrated along coastlines and water bodies. 
The region relies heavily on agriculture, the most climate vulnerable sector, for livelihood. 
Although the region’s contribution to global greenhouse emissions is relatively low, Intended 
Nationally Determined Contributions under the Paris Agreement on Climate Change identifies the 
region’s  increasing  energy  use  in  agriculture,  industry,  and  transportation,  together  with 
deforestation and land-use change as the main factors for the rise in greenhouse gas emissions.8 
An Asian Development Bank (ADB) study projected that the region may lose up to 11% of gross 
domestic product by 2100 if no action is taken to address climate change.9 
                                                
7  Average agricultural land per capita ranges from 0.36 hectare in Cambodia as the largest and 0.12 hectare in Viet 
Nam as the smallest. 
8  Synthesis of intended nationally determined contributions as communicated by Parties. United Nations Framework 
Convention on Climate Change. Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (accessed 12 November 2018). 
9  ADB. 2015. ADB Brief “Southeast Asia and the Economics of Global Climate Stabilization”. Manila.

3 
 
3.  Opportunities 
 
9.  Growing hub of global agro-based value chains and regional integration. As one of 
the fastest growing regions in the world characterized with rich agricultural resources, the region 
has had some success in integrating into the global agro-based value chains with countries 
outside the region and in increasing the value chain linkages within the region. To enable the 
region to grow as the hub of safe and environment-friendly agro-based value chains, ADB 
facilitated the ministerial level agreement Siem Reap Action Plan 2018–2022 for the Greater 
Mekong Subregion.10 This action plan is in line with the ASEAN Economic Community Blueprint 
2025, which places a strategic importance to the ANR sector.11 
 
10.  Promotion  of  advanced  technologies.  Application  of  advanced  technologies  to 
agriculture is on the rise. Advanced technologies vary from agricultural machinery, biotechnology 
for seeds and agricultural chemicals, and satellite imaging to more recent technologies such as 
internet of things, drones, and robotics. They enable farmers to access critical information and 
improve farming operations and marketing of their products. Buyers of farm products can better 
communicate  with  farmers  and  manage  supplies  and  inventory  more  efficiently.  Advanced 
technologies will also help establish food traceability systems, which are increasingly in demand 
by consumers. 
 
11.  The TA facility will help prepare and implement investment projects that will address the 
above-mentioned challenges and capitalize on the opportunities. These projects will continue to 
(i) promote the use of climate-smart agricultural practices; (ii) promote the adoption of advanced 
technologies such as satellite and drone-assisted applications to increase irrigation efficiency; 
(iii) ensure  the  sustainable  use  of  land  and  water  resources;  and  (iv)  enhance  disaster 
preparedness  and  climate  resilience.  The  projects  will  strengthen  public  infrastructure  and 
services (e.g., irrigation, rural roads, public markets, and food safety-related facilities and services) 
to create enabling ANR sector development and business environments for agro-based value 
chain stakeholders (e.g., private agribusiness entities and farmer cooperatives). They will also 
promote private sector investment to accelerate growth by increasing productivity and adding 
value, and ensure the quality of growth by improving food safety and environmental controls. The 
projects will also promote efficiency in resource use, especially in the post-harvest segments of 
agro-based value chains. They will incorporate gender designs and targets to improve and 
support women’s participation in the ANR sector.  
 
12.  The  TA  facility  will  support  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  and  its  operational  priorities  by 
(i) promoting rural development and food security; (ii) addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities; (iii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing 
environmental  sustainability;  (iv)  fostering  regional  cooperation  and  integration;  and 
(v) accelerating progress in gender equality.12  
 
                                                
10 ADB. 2017. Strategy for Promoting Safe and Environment-Friendly Agro-Based Value Chains in the Greater Mekong 
Subregion and Siem Reap Action Plan, 2018-2022. Bangkok. 
11 ASEAN. 2015. ASEAN Economic Community Blueprint 2025. Jakarta. The blueprint promotes the following areas 
relevant to the ANR sector: (i) increased participation in global value chains; (ii) sustainable economic development 
particularly promotion of economic growth and environment and natural resources protection in tandem; and 
(iii) micro-, small-, medium-sized enterprises development. 
12 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

4 
B.  Output and Activities 
 
13.  Output 1: ANR sector projects prepared. The TA facility will assist the DMCs in 
preparing projects for ADB financing. This will include due diligence assessments including 
(i) technical suitability, (ii) economic and financial viability, (iii) governance, (iv) poverty impact 
and social and gender development, and (v) social and environment safeguards.13 During the TA 
facility implementation, lessons learned from previous projects will be incorporated into the 
preparation of new projects. 
 
14.  Output 2: Project implementation support, capacity development, and policy advice 
provided. The facility will provide the DMCs with (i) project implementation support; (ii) capacity 
development in procurement, financial management and disbursement, safeguards, and project-
related technical aspects; and (ii) policy advisory and sector assessments. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $3,500,000, of which (i) $2,600,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($1,600,000 from TASF 6 and 
$1,000,000 from TASF-other sources); and (ii) $900,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Project Readiness Improvement Trust Fund (PRITF) and administered by ADB.14 
 
16.  The PRITF will help incorporate climate change proofing in the project design and improve 
project  readiness.  The  key  expenditure  items  are  listed  in  Appendix  1.  ADB  will  explore 
cofinancing opportunities with other trust funds such as Water Financing Partnership Facility, 
High-Level Technology Fund, and other funds from development partners including Agence 
Française de Développement. 
 
17.  The  governments  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  staff  time,  office 
accommodation,  office  supplies,  communication  facilities  for  consultants,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. Activities in each participating DMC will start after obtaining no-objection from their 
government. The governments were informed that approval of the TA facility does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  Output 1 activities will start after ADB approves the concept paper of the first ensuing loan 
covered by the TA facility. Output 2 activities may commence upon approval of the TA facility. 
ADB will administer the TA. The Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division of the 
Southeast Asia Department of ADB will be responsible for the implementation of the TA facility. 
The  TA  facility  will  be  implemented  over  5  years,  commencing  in  January  2019.  The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1. 
  
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation  January 2019–December 2023 
period

Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB

14 Financing partner: Nordic Development Fund.

5

ADB = Asian Development Bank, CAIMS = Climate Adaptation through Irrigation Modernization Sector Project,        
DMC = developing member country, IAID II = Irrigated Agriculture Inclusive Development Project II, QCBS = quality-  
and cost- based selection, RBCCE =  Rural Business Commercialization and Competitiveness Enhancement, TA = 
technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
19.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and staff instructions. Consultants will be engaged utilizing two selection methods: quality- and 
cost-based selection (QCBS) (90:10) and individual consultant selection. The QCBS package will 
offer consulting for project preparation support and will be procured in two steps. First, three to 
five consulting firms will be selected as prequalified consultants that are eligible to submit 
proposals for preparation of all the ensuing projects under the TA facility. Second, one of these 
prequalified consultants will be selected through the QCBS method to prepare a specific ensuing 
project once the project concept is approved. For individual consultant selection packages, 
consultants  will  be  engaged  for  specialized  technical  and  administrative  inputs  to  either 
complement consultants in the QCBS packages or support implementation of ongoing or ensuing 
projects. The terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  Detailed engineering design. The detailed engineering design (DED) will be financed by 
PRITF. PRITF implementation guidelines permit financing of DEDs. ADB’s project processing 
team for the relevant project has discussed and agreed with the relevant government agency on 
the scope and implementation arrangements, including the explicit clause in consultant contracts 
to hold the consultants accountable for any defect liability arising from the DED. This agreement 
has  been  formalized  in  a  signed  memorandum  of  understanding  between  ADB  and  the 
government agency for the ensuing project. 
 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Project Readiness Improvement Trust Fund; and (ii) ADB 
providing  the  balance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $2,600,000  from  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Special Fund on a grant basis for the Southeast Asia Agriculture, Natural Resources 
and Rural Development Facility, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
                Takehiko Nakao 
President 
10 December 2018

6  Appendix 1
